questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about the Fork/Join Framework? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The Fork/Join solution when run on multicore hardware always performs faster than standard sequential solution.
choices.B: The Fork/Join framework can help you take advantage of multicore hardware.
choices.C: The Fork/Join framework implements a work-stealing algorithm.
choices.A: The RecursiveTask subclass is used when a task does not need to return a result.

choices.E: Threads cannot acquire intrinsic locks on classes.
choices.D: A thread automatically acquires the intrinsic lock on a synchronized method's object when entering that method.
choices.B: The intrinsic lock will be retained by a thread if return from a synchronized method is caused by an uncaught exception.
choices.C: A thread exclusively owns the intrinsic lock of an object between the time it acquires the lock and the time it releases it.
choices.A: A thread automatically acquires the intrinsic lock on a synchronized statement when executed.

discussion.content: the correct answers are C and D.

Selected Answer: CD
C and D should be correct.

Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct
C and D are correct

C and D are correct!
A is wrong. -> synchronized statement won’t acquires “intrinsic lock” but a specified object that provides the intrinsic lock
B is wrong -> The lock release occurs even if the return was caused by an uncaught exception.
